div.p: S. D. I have labored in your cause, most distinguished and eternally esteemed man, as much as my limited abilities allowed, and I hope that the matter has turned out very well. Just yesterday, a decision was made in the council, the content of which you will understand from the letters of the magistrate; for I also believe this to be very auspicious, that the magistrate himself diligently informs you of his goodwill and benevolence.

You therefore have the sealed letters, and there is no reason for some conditions to trouble you; I am very hopeful about all matters. For I have understood that the senators' disposition towards you is most favorable.

Above all, however, pray to our omnipotent and truly wise God, that He may direct your paths. I would have preferred to send the messenger today if the scribe had prepared the letters; but due to business, he could not; he only sent them this evening. I have now sent them to you through this messenger, sent for this purpose only, most esteemed man; he is diligent and poor. Furthermore, if I can do anything for the favor of you and yours, I offer myself most ready for your services.
Farewell and keep me commended to you.
To the most excellent man, Mr. Thomas Blaurer, his most esteemed lord and friend. Griesenberg.
May 24, 1549, by the Zurich messenger Andreas Sorseus/Sorsen? from Geneva.
